data.title: Veteran sub Gerald Green serves as mentor for younger Celtics

data.text:
DALLAS — Though all the Celtics veterans are available when a younger player needs advice, there’s another, older newcomer who has more in common with those trying to earn more minutes.

Gerald Green has been there, as they all know, trying to get Doc Rivers’ attention as a rookie in 2005-06, and inviting as much doubt as encouragement from the former Celtics coach. Green knows the difficulty of earning time, even if the C’s were a 24-win team back then.

So Green’s heart goes out to rookie Jaylen Brown, second-year player Terry Rozier and James Young, who has spent huge chunks of his career languishing in the corner.

Then comes a night like Saturday’s in Salt Lake City, where Marcus Smart went down with a cramp in the second quarter. Young came in, missed his first two shots, and, true to the advice of Green and the coaches, kept shooting. He hit a pair of big 3-pointers down the stretch on his way to 10 points in the win against the Jazz. He also took a few turns guarding Utah’s Gordon Hayward, showing why the Celtics coaches say Young’s greatest improvement may be in the defensive end.

The 30-year-old Green, who scored 16 points in an elevated role in the absence of Avery Bradley and Jae Crowder, once again sounded like a very wise man.

“I’ve talked to (Green) a lot, and heard him talk about the little things, and the opportunities and how my time is going to come,” Young said. “That’s all I can do.”

And Green, as it turns out, relishes this role as the well-traveled, world-weary veteran.

“I have accepted that role,” Green said. “I know James is a kid who reminds me of myself early in my career, trying to figure out a way to step on the floor, playing behind good players. The difference between him and me is I wasn’t on a team that was very good. He’s on a team that’s really good.

“I tell him to stay ready, keep doing the things you need to do, keep preparing yourself as if you’re going to play every day, and one of these moments we’re going to need you to win a game. And this was that moment for him. He came in the second half — that’s tough, I know. But he came in, and to guard the way he was guarding and knocking shots down, he’s one of the reasons we won.”

Overall, though, Green is impressed by everyone in the C’s locker room, for a very specific reason.

“This group is resilient, man. A lot of times we just don’t give up,” he said. “A lot of times we ease up, but we don’t give up. We just keep going, fighting. Someone in this locker room is always trying to figure out a way to get better — even the coaching staff. I’ve been on teams in Indiana and Miami that were pretty good too, but as far as trying to get better, this team is the same. We still have a long way to go, but I love the mentality we have.”

Sort of like the mentality Green has brought back to his original NBA team. Once on the floor, he fires away. Green’s not Vinnie Johnson, but he has some of the same wiring.

“Man, I don’t know,” Green said of how he’s able to come into a game cold and immediately start hitting shots. “Just have to prepare yourself that you’re going to play. Some games you might not play and some games I might get in a little bit. Before the game you have to treat yourself like you’re going to play a lot — just treat yourself to the same routine.”

Celtics notes

Walter McCarty knew Fab Melo longer than anyone in the Celtics organization, dating back to when he was part of the recruiting effort to bring the big Brazilian to Louisville. When McCarty rejoined the Celtics organization prior to the 2012-13 season, Melo was a rookie, taken with the 22nd pick. It’s hard for the assistant coach to conceive of Melo, who reportedly died in his sleep of cardiac arrest on Saturday in Brazil, passing at the age of 26.

“Very nice guy, a person always fun to be around,” McCarty said. “My prayers go out to his family. It was a tough loss. He should have had more time on this earth. It’s very sad. You just never know when your time may be. Very tough. As successful as he was, it was tough to see that happen to him.” . . .

Jae Crowder, who missed the last two games to tend to a family medical issue in Dallas, will rejoin the team for tonight’s game against the Mavericks. Just in time, as it turns out. Brown, whose minutes load had increased in Crowder’s absence, strained his hip against the Jazz and didn’t return.

Coach Brad Stevens already ruled out Bradley for tonight.

Bradley missed 17 games with a strained right Achilles, and continues to get treatment at the team’s practice facility in Waltham. He is not expected to return until after the All-Star break.
